Agudeza Ontology
  • Data Processing
  • Ontology Design
  • Knowledge Representation
  • Knowledge Extraction

Data Processing

Mapping the general landscape of the domain through the analysis of 3 data sources

Initial Assumptions


Before beginning a formal process of data analysis in order to ascertain quantifiably and objectively the landscape of the domain, an intuitive and informal mapping is presented below.

This mapping is sourced from my own PhD thesis entitled “Acquired Ingenuity: The Conflation of Prudence With Ingenio in the Works of Baltasar Gracián” (full thesis available here). In particular, it represents a reverse-engineering of the argument of chapter 4 of this thesis, which deals specifically with the Agudeza.

The result is an incredibly complex, intricate, and somewhat overwhelming system of interlinkages between branches of philosophy and key terms particular to Gracián’s idiolect.

The aim of the data processing to follow is to ensure that this informal mapping accurately aligns with the critical landscape more generally, ensuring that the Agudeza Ontology, its foundational requirements and competency questions, are applicable for describing and querying critical stances other than my own.

Data Sources


The data which forms the basis of the Agudeza Ontology has been extracted from three sources:

  • Two complementary articles entitled “Gracián’s Agudeza y arte de ingenio”, written by Edward Sarmiento and published in 1932
  • An article entitled “‘Concept’ and ‘Conceit’: An Aspect of Comparative Literary History”, written by Alexander Parker and published in 1982
  • A chapter entitled “The ‘Agudeza y arte de ingenio’” from my own PhD thesis, the overall title of which is “Acquired Ingenuity: The Conflation of Prudence With Ingenio in the Works of Baltasar Gracián”, submitted in 2020

These pieces of scholarship have been chosen to represent the state of scholarship on Gracián’s Agudeza at separate and discrete points of time, allowing consistencies and developments in scholarship across time to emerge clearly and to be taken into account in the construction of the Agudeza Ontology.

Cleaning the Data


The first step in the process of being able to use these articles as data sources was to process and clean them. This involved completely standardising their format. Within Notebook++ the following steps were taken using regular expression searches:

  • Paragraphs were eliminated
  • All punctuation marks were eliminated (full stops, commas, colons, semi-colons, double quotation marks, single quotation marks, brackets, hyphens, question marks, forward slashes, and ellipses)
  • All numbers were eliminated
  • Signifiers of possession in the form "’s" were eliminated, leaving just the primary word

The txt files of the cleaned data sources can be found here.

Processing the Data


A series of functions were written in Python to enable processing of the data. These included:

  • A function to tokenise the text into a list of separate strings
  • A function to create a dictionary of how many times each token appears
  • A function to remove certain stopwords from the previous dictionary. These were chosen after careful consideration of their singularity and importance within the context of the Agudeza:
    • Many stopwords represent common parts of speech which are negligible for nearly every computational analysis, regardless of context (for example: subject pronouns, definite and indefinite articles, possessive pronouns, demonstrative adjectives, and modal verb forms)
    • Other stopwords were included based upon the particular context of this analysis (for example: words denoting structural components of literary texts, common verbs such as ‘argues’, ‘describes’, ‘highlights’, or ‘indicates’, and common phrases marking the progression of academic argument such as ‘although’, ‘however’, ‘nevertheless’, or ‘therefore’)
  • A function to remove tokens which appear 3 times or less from the previous dictionary
  • A function to return a new dictionary containing only the top 150 tokens
  • A function to convert this new dictionary into a Pandas DataFrame
  • A function to save the aforementioned DataFrame as a CSV file

The code of these functions can be seen below.



The 3 critical examinations of Gracián’s Agudeza which make up the source data of this project were inputted into each of these functions, resulting in a CSV file of the top 150 tokens for each critic’s work. This allows us to compare and contrast key terms and their prevalence within the approach of each critic. These CSV files are available here.

Data Analysis: Similarities


Observation of the CSV files of the 150 most frequent tokens used by each critic allows us to form logical groups of terms which share the same lexical space. These groupings help us to begin to formulate an idea of the key classes of ideas which make up the critical universe of the Agudeza. The following are the lexical groupings observed.

  • Rhetoric and language
  • Connection-making
  • Aestheticism/divinity
  • Worldliness/earthliness
  • Areas of philosophy
  • Intellectual faculties
  • Critics
  • Figures/movements of influence on Gracián
  • Other texts by Gracián
  • Key terms

The tables below provide the tokens from each of the 3 critics, justifying the lexical groupings above. A brief summary of what the information in each table shows is also provided.

  • Rhetoric

  • Connections

  • Aestheticism

  • Worldliness

  • Philosophy

  • Intellect

  • Symbols

  • Critics

  • Influences

  • Other texts

  • Key terms

Observation: All critics place an equal degree of focus on the idea of rhetoric and language.

Observation: Beattie considers more philosophical branches in her analysis.

Observation: In terms of the intellectual faculties all critics address the idea of reason but differ within this.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie

Observation: Different symbols are used by each critic: those of Sarmiento pertain to fire and light; those of Parker pertain, generally, to love; those of Beattie pertain to darkness and light.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie

Observation: Sarmiento references no other critics in his analysis, while Parker mentions only Sarmiento. Beattie references many.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Classical Martial Martial Sarbiewski Góngora Marino Tasso Classical Jesuits Peregrini Italian Suárez Cave(Platonism)

Observation: Parker considers the biggest range of influences on Gracián and agrees with Sarmiento on the influence of Classicism; Beattie does not mention this at all.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
- - Andrenio Criticón Critilo Héroe Fiction Narrative

Observation: Only Beattie infuses her analysis with a consideration of Gracián’s other works; Sarmiento and Parker consider the ‘Agudeza’ in isolation.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Conceit Agudeza Conceits Conceptist Ingenio Reason Concepto Concept Conceit Wit Witty Concepto Agudeza Concept Conceits Concetto Concetti Concepts Ingenio Conceptus Conceptismo Acutezza Reason Agudeza Ingenio Concepto Conceptus Ser Parecer Conceit Concept Reason

Observation: There are several key terms which are the focus of all critics’ analyses: Parker considers this in an international context (Spanish and Italian) and has several words, in translation, which represent the same ideas.

Data Analysis: Differences in Prevalence of Key Terms


As is to be expected, there are several key terms which appear frequently in the work of all 3 critics. However, given they are key terms within the critical debate, it is worth noting the position at which each word appears in the frequency table of each critic. The following tables provide information on the frequency of each key term within the analysis of each critic, as well as its position in the top 150 tokens. Even when bearing in mind the different lengths of each critical anaylsis, these observations are insightful.

  • Ingenio

  • Agudeza

  • Concepto

  • Conceit

  • Conceptus

  • Wit

  • Reason

  • Gusto

  • Ser

  • Parecer
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 13 10 101
Position 14 28 2

Observation: The idea of ‘ingenio’ is central for Beattie, while it is of secondary importance for Sarmiento and Parker.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 39 24 185
Position 3 4 1

Observation: The idea of ‘agudeza’ is a key focus of all three critics.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Conceptos: 13; Concepto: 7 Conceptos: 13; Concepto: 41 95
Position Conceptos: 25; Concepto: 54 Conceptos: 19; Concepto: 3 15

Observation: The idea of the ‘concepto’ is a key focus of all three critics.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Conceit: 111; Conceits: 16 Conceit: 52; Conceits: 18 22
Position Conceit: 1; Conceits: 11 Conceit: 1; Conceits: 10 15

Observation: The idea of the ‘conceit’ is a central idea for all key critics, but it is the prime focus for Sarmiento and Parker, while it is of secondary focus for Beattie.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Absent 7 33
Position Absent 53 7

Observation: For Beattie and Parker ‘conceptus’ is a key idea, while it is not considered at all by Sarmiento. ‘Conceptus’ is a more prominent idea for Beattie than it is for Parker.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Absent Wit: 54; Witty: 13 Absent
Position Absent Wit: 2; Witty: 20 Absent

Observation: For Parker ‘wit’ is one of the most important ideas, while it is not considered at all by Sarmiento and Beattie.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 9 4 17
Position 32 142 22

Observation: The idea of ‘reason’ is of relatively high importance for Sarmiento and Beattie, but of low importance for Parker.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Absent Absent 7
Position Absent Absent 100

Observation: For Beattie, 'gusto' is a key term, but it is not considered at all by Sarmiento and Parker.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Absent Absent 25
Position Absent Absent 10

Observation: For Beattie, 'ser' is a key term, but it is not considered at all by Sarmiento and Parker.

Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency Absent Absent 25
Position Absent Absent 11

Observation: For Beattie, 'parecer' is a key term, but it is not considered at all by Sarmiento and Parker.

Despite using the same vocabulary – the vocabulary of the primary text text after all – the critics clearly place different emphases on different facets of Gracián’s thought, implying that their understanding of each key term may be different.

Taking a close look at the way in which key terms are used and understood by each critic is important at this stage, allowing us to begin to conceptualise the ways in which critics differ in their analyses of Gracián’s Agudeza - differences in approach that the Agudeza Ontology can express, map, and represent.
